pr_title: SQL: change the way unsupported data types fields are handled

timeline.message:
Properly ignore (for the moment) the "flattened" data type, treating it
as of UNSUPPORTED type
Merge branch 'master' of https://github.com/elastic/elasticsearch into ignore_flattened_fields

timeline.bodyText: I wonder if we cannot make this a bit generic by looking for field names that have leaves starting with _ and if so, look at their type  - if its not recognized, mark the field as unsupported.
timeline.author: costin

timeline.message: Make the unsupported fields handling a generic one
Merge branch 'master' of https://github.com/elastic/elasticsearch into ignore_flattened_fields

timeline.author: matriv

timeline.message: Merge branch 'master' of https://github.com/elastic/elasticsearch into ignore_flattened_fields

Added a way to remember the first unsupported data type in a hierarchy
of fields to improve error reporting
Merge branch 'master' of https://github.com/elastic/elasticsearch into ignore_flattened_fields
Merge branch 'master' of https://github.com/elastic/elasticsearch into ignore_flattened_fields

timeline.bodyText:
The whole block can be further simplified by
esField = new UnsupportedEsField(esField.getName(), type, inherited != null ? inherited : unsupportedParent.getName(), esField.getProperties());
timeline.author: costin

timeline.bodyText: Why is the if needed - the result will be the same regardless of whether field is UnsupportedEsField or not.
timeline.author: costin
costin

timeline.bodyText: Why is propagated needed? The parents should always be discovered before children which means an unsupported parent will discovered before its children, which in turn, will already know their parent is unsupported and thus become unsupported as well.
timeline.author: costin

replies.bodyText:
@costin  If I remember well, the method pair startWalking-walkMapping does the discovery the other way around: start with a mapping looking like parent=[child=[another_child=[type:keyword]], type:text], type:foobar]], get the parent, look at properties like "it's nested", or "it's object", or "has sub-fields" here, if yes, dig into those and so on and so forth.
Then after discovering all the children, create the parent itself here. So, by the time the algorithm finds out that a root field is unsupported, the children already have some types (their own).
replies.author: astefan

replies.bodyText: This approach is used only in the case of some tests that use a .json file with mappings. I made this change because I wanted to also test the error message (here) that gets printed out from the Analyzer.
replies.author: astefan
